Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Award: DMS-0503444
Principal Investigator: Justin T. Moore

The Boise Extravaganza in Set Theory is an annual three day
conference at Boise State University devoted to set theory and
related areas of mathematics such as algebra, analysis,
combinatorics, logic, and topology. It has occurred continuously
since the first conference in 1992. This proposal is a request
for travel and lodging support for the invited speakers and
participants who attend the conference (particularly students and
junior researchers). The main goals of the conference are as
follows: (1) Provide the Western US with an annual conference in
set theory; (2) Provide an organized low-cost event accessible to
graduate students and young researchers; (3) Provide an
opportunity for interaction between the leaders in the field and
set theorists early in their careers; (4) Provide a forum for
interactions between set theory and related areas of mathematics;
(5) Represent the many different sub-disciplines within set
theory; (6) Encourage participation by women and minorities when
possible.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported hosting the conference ``Boise Extravaganza in Set Theory" (BEST) during the five years from 2006 to 2010. Including these five years, the BEST conference has been hosted annually during the early Spring at Boise university for 19 years.

Set Theory is one of the foundations of infinitary Mathematics. Development of Set Theory received its greatest impetus from  the discovery, by Georg Cantor (1870's), of the fact that there are different infinite cardinalities, from the axiomatization of the theory by Zermelo and Fraenkel (1900's), from the fundamental discoveries of G\"odel (1930's) and Cohen (1960's) that there are mathematical statements that are not provable from the axioms, and from the discovery that certain ``large cardinal hypotheses" can be used to measure the relative strength of mathematical statements. Numerous mathematical problems from other areas of mathematics have since been proven to be similarly not provable, or have had their deductive strength calibrated by means of large cardinals. The intellectual focus of the BEST conference is the field of Set Theory and its applications in mathematics.

During each of these five grant supported meetings mathematicians affiliated with academic institutions in Austria, Canada, France, Germany, Great Britain, Hungary, Israel, Japan, Mexico, Poland, Serbia and the United States of America met for two and a half days during the early Spring. Each of these meetings featured three to four invited speakers, and a number of contributed talks. The invited speakers were always selected to represent role models from two demographics in the field: Half the invited speakers were established senior mathematicians, while the other half were prominent early career mathematicians.

The conference gives special attention to promoting the participation of women, minorities and graduate students, and to fostering an atmosphere in which mathematicians from different career stages could establish professional contact. A number of fruitful collaborations have been spawned during these meetings.


Last Modified: 02/05/2011
Modified by: Marion Scheepers
